questions.question: What is the primary function of a multiplexer (MUX) in digital logic circuits?
options: To store a single bit of data.
To perform arithmetic operations like addition.
To combine multiple input signals into a single output signal based on a select input.
To convert analog signals to digital signals.
To generate a clock signal.

questions.question: In digital IC design, what is the primary purpose of incorporating 'scan chains' into a circuit?
options: To reduce the dynamic power consumption of the chip.
To improve the circuit's performance by reducing critical path delay.
To facilitate testing of sequential logic elements by allowing their states to be easily set and observed.
To ensure electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) of the chip with its environment.
To protect intellectual property (IP) from unauthorized copying.

questions.question: In computer architecture, what is the primary distinguishing characteristic of a Very Long Instruction Word (VLIW) processor compared to a superscalar processor?
options: VLIW processors use a deep pipeline to increase instruction throughput.
VLIW processors rely on hardware-based dynamic scheduling to find instruction-level parallelism at runtime.
VLIW processors execute multiple operations in parallel based on explicit scheduling by the compiler.
VLIW processors only execute one instruction per clock cycle but at a very high frequency.
VLIW processors exclusively use an in-order execution model.

questions.question: As transistor dimensions continue to shrink into the nanometer regime (e.g., below 7nm), which fundamental quantum mechanical phenomenon increasingly contributes to leakage current and poses a significant challenge for circuit reliability and power consumption?
options: Doppler effect.
Photoelectric effect.
Quantum tunneling.
Hall effect.
Thermionic emission.

questions.question: In computer architecture, what is the primary distinction of 'memory-mapped I/O' compared to 'port-mapped I/O' (or isolated I/O)?
options: Memory-mapped I/O uses a dedicated set of instructions for I/O operations, separate from memory access instructions.
Memory-mapped I/O devices share the same address space as main memory, allowing them to be accessed using standard memory load/store instructions.
Memory-mapped I/O requires a separate I/O bus, distinct from the system memory bus.
Memory-mapped I/O prevents direct memory access (DMA) by peripheral devices.
Memory-mapped I/O is exclusively used in Harvard architectures, while port-mapped I/O is used in Von Neumann architectures.
